messages.message: It depends a lot on their docs and workload, and the provisioning of the cluster (e.g. how many celery-app-task workers are there?). I think @tony.shi and @Anil benchmarked OpenAI requests / tokens with some of our standard load testing configurations.

On the last bullet, this depends on what they ask. If they are extracting simple fields (date, name, address), I would expect this number to be pretty low compared to the prompt request. If they are extracting list of items (e.g. explanation of benefits, claims table), then it can be similar in size (at least same order of magnitude) as the prompt request.

Is the purpose of their question because they want to get a sense of how much spend they'll have on Azure OpenAI? To answer this question, we would need from them the list of classes, fields and document lengths (pages can be a reasonable approximation depending on the type of document) they are planning to process.

> pages can be a reasonable approximation depending on the type of document
This is because tokens are approximately words, not pages. So for natural language docs, we can approximate a word count per page, but other doc types might be really dense (e.g. tax form instruction pages) with small-font text.
Do we have any metrics in our system that we can leverage for this to get a sense of the tokens per page they are consuming?
This is a pre-sales effort for Nationwide, they are trying to understand the cost of using their Azure Open AI with AI Hub.  We have information on the schema, and document volumes.
Great! Let's wait to see if Anil/Tony have some numbers we can use. We can then scale their load testing numbers to the volume Nationwide expects
cc @tony.shi can you help with this

Yep! We did some testing on this late last year and the results can be found here (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yUaYuBcRl_Sfw2ZRdJX8bgm5aGG_gAPBo_LO2oe5pXQ/edit?usp=sharing)

In summary, the number of input/completion tokens expected heavily depends on the nature of the application as well as the input set.
